All events with a reminder would have a 'bell' icon. If you normally have reminders set to pop up 1 day before then it would limit what to check as you are likely to remember those you knowingly dismissed.

The Activities Manager only does mail downloads, server connection, move delete emails. I'm not aware of any Calendar activity manager.

content:
I guess that this is how to save a Profile copy?

How to backup your profile with the Export tool Do ≡ > Tools > Export. Click on the Export button. In the Export to a ZIP file dialog, choose a target folder and file name, e.g. Thunderbird_profile_backup_2022-06-28. zip. Click Save.
creator: RonSH

content: That works if the profile isn't very big. My preferred approach is to exit TB (important step) and then to copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to a USB stick or other folder. Then, should you need to restore it, just copy it back (again, with TB not running).

content: You mention multiple profiles. Normally, the profile is in the users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder, but that's not the one you said you used. Also, Thunderbird does not automatically recognize the right profile, but looks at the profiles.ini file to tell it which to open. If it is a new install, it creates an empty profile, which is probably what you see. I suggest you exit TB and use windows file explorer to browse the profiles and determine the one that has most recently been used, as that is probably your preferred profile. My thought then would be to copy that profile into the thunderbird\profiles folder, start TB, click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles', click 'about:profiles' and then select that profile from the list.
creator: davidsk

content:
Hi David and thanks for responding. Your information about profiles is useful to know but I have decided to take a 'sledgehammer' approach which will probably distress the technical purists but (spoiler alert) seemed to work..

I uninstalled TB then did a clean install and did not register any accounts. The help/troubleshootinginformation etc was not available in this empty installation, but on looking at the c:\users\my id\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder, only jdz1j2bt.default-release and pnze9235.default were present, so I guess they're the active folders. I closed TB, made a backup copy of the first one of those just in case then deleted its entire contents. Then I copied the entire contents of my desktop backup of Profiles/1oltjdxc.default folder (which seemed to have all my accounts, archives, contacts etc in it) and pasted them in. Restarted TB, holding my breath.

Bingo. Everything is back. Case closed, except I'm still left with my original problem of TB not communicating with my British Telecom server which nobody has responded to. If that doesn't get fixed soon I will either have to abandon TB for Outlook or something or migrate to a new non-BT email address and tell the world, neither of which appeals.
creator: billhamilton.1

content: I admit that I occasionally use a hammer - a big one. I'm glad all is well. :)

content:
I specifically mentioned mail scanning, but my understanding of bitdefender is it has all sorts of nasty bits that are supposed to be helpful and can only be deemed a problem when they do not work like clockwork. Including scanning all encrypted connections, an anti spam toolbar that has caused much difficult in the past as well as a habit of forcing updates before the development team even authorize them for existing users. So forgive me if I am not convinced that yet again an anti virus product struggles following a software update of Thunderbird.

I suggest you try your operating system in safe mode with networking and see if you issues continue while in that mode.

Safe mode instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

content: How to check Auth2 for outgoing and incoming servers? Best regards, Muhammad.
creator: muhammed3198

content: Open Account Settings, select Server Settings for the gmail account in the left pane, then check Authentication method in the right pane. Select Outgoing Server (SMTP) at the bottom of the left pane in Account Settings, then select the gmail smtp server in the right pane to view its settings.

content:
I am simply completely confused.

  • Your topic title is "How do I change the Cursor size in email Inbox TB 102.15.1"
  • The post is accompanied with an image where you are searching for ui.caretwidth. This is a fully qualified setting in the config editor and something that can be changed in the config editor.

content:
P Brixey said
I checked out the link but it only applies to Firefox browsers.
Except that Firefox and Thunderbird are basically the same thing in as much as both are built on the Mozilla platform. (used to be called Geko) so many low level things are actually identical, excepting for Firefox having an about:config page and Thunderbird having a config editor to access hidden preferences.

I checked my TBird installs on my Win10 and Win11 machines, the installs are the same with identical settings. I have attached screen captures of both inboxes. You will notice that there is a huge difference between the scrollbars for Win10 and Win11 installs. One odd thing I noticed with the win11 one is that the microscopic scroll bar disappears when the mouse cursor is not moved into the window. I don't mean clicked, I mean just moved. It does not do that with the Win10 one, the scrollbar remains fully visible. Errrr....

The narrow scrollbars are a "feature" of windows 11. This article discussed both turning them on permanently and adjusting their width which requires changes at the registry level. Good luck.

P Brixey said
To many, the little "Thing" in the scrollbar on the right of the inbox that moves up and down when scrolling in the inbox was known as a cursor. Oops, eh? Terminology will get us every time. I am not sure what its correct name is, perhaps you could enlighten me.

To me the insertion point that blinks on an off in a text box or word processor is the cursor, or from my programming days 20 years ago a caret. I also tried to confirm my assumption, old as it is, and find all these folk calling the mouse pointer a cursor and offering downloads of fancy replacements. So really I have no idea what is right or wrong. Just that I did not understand :)

I had never really considered what that little square thing would be called, so I went off to Google. Looks like according to Microsoft, "A scroll bar consists of a shaded shaft with an arrow button at each end and a scroll box (sometimes called a thumb) between the arrow buttons." (1)

content:
First, I do not have a quick answer to your issue. BUT, I suggest being careful on fiddling with profile changes. Recreating a fresh profile is a long process to get all your accounts setup, plus whatever local folders you have. I'll answer your last question: backing up. Assuming your profile is in default location and that you use windows, I suggest first exiting Thunderbird (VERY important) and then copying c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to a USB stick or other folder. That ensures nothing will be lost if you have to later copy it back. On your next-to-last question, Yes, Thunderbird can keep prior profiles available. If you create a new profile, you can switch by help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles.'

I also suggest you post more specifics on your problem, as someone here may have a suggested solution. Good luck.
creator: davidsk

content:
If your Android syncs Google calendars and Contacts, it's just a matter of adding the calendars as CalDAV calendars (File/New/Calendar... On the Network... enter gmail address...) and adding the Contacts as CardDAV address books (in Address Book, New Address Book, Add CardDAV Address Book, enter gmail address...).

Other providers are supported either through the built-in method as above or with add-ons, e.g. for outlook.com.
